revision.text:
{{distinguish|Edd Byrnes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Use Irish English|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox comedian | image = Ed_Byrne.jpg | name = Ed Byrne | birth_name = Edward Cathal Byrne | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|04|10|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Swords, Dublin|Swords]], [[Dublin]], Ireland | caption = Byrne after ''Different Class''
at the [[Lowry Centre]], 2009 | medium = [[Comedian]], [[actor]] | active = 1995–present | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[Satire|social satire]] | spouse = Claire Walker (m. 2008) | children = 2 | religion = }} '''Edward Cathal Byrne'''{{cite web |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/podcasts/richard_herring_edinburgh/2013_22_ed_byrne_bridget_christie/ |title=2013 #22: Ed Byrne, Bridget Christie and Luke Wright - Richard Herring's Edinburgh Fringe Podcast |website=British Comedy Guide |date=23 August 2012 |accessdate=12 January 2014}} (born 10 April 1972)[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0126170/] is an Irish [[stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]], [[voice over artist]] and actor. He has presented television shows ''Uncut! Best Unseen Ads'' and ''[[Just for Laughs (UK TV series)|Just for Laughs]]'', and is a guest on television [[panel game]]s. As an actor, he played the title character in the 2000 [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] adaptation of the pantomime ''[[Aladdin#Adaptations|Aladdin]]''. ==Early life== Byrne was born in [[Swords, Dublin|Swords]], [[Dublin]], in [[Ireland]], in 1972, to Jill and Eddie Byrne, the third of four children.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} ==Career== ===Stand-up comedy=== Deciding to study [[horticulture]] at the [[University of Strathclyde]], he was made entertainments convener at the [[Students' Union]] in his second year of study. Byrne started a comedy night called ''[[International Comedy Cellar|The Comedy Cellar]]'' in the basement of the 13th Note [[public house]] on Glassford Street, [[Glasgow]]. On the first night, Byrne appeared on the roster alongside [[Armando Ianucci]]'s brother David. Over the following few months, acts booked included [[Ford Kiernan]], [[Phil Kay]], [[Greg Hemphill]], [[Alan Francis (writer)|Alan Francis]] and Alan Tyler. After a few months he gave up studying and headed to [[London]]. He was later booked to appear at ''The Comedy Cellar'' by new convenors Ford Kiernan and J.P. Leach.{{cite news |first=Brian |last=McIver |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-interviews/2011/03/06/smaller-venues-are-much-better-for-comedy-not-massive-arenas-says-irish-comic-ed-byrne-86908-22970549/ |title=Smaller venues are much better for comedy - not massive arenas, says Irish comic Ed Byrne |newspaper=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=12 January 2014}} After building up his act on [[observational comedy]], Byrne was nominated for the prestigious [[Perrier Comedy Award]] at the 1998 [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]]. In 2006 he toured the UK, recording a DVD in [[Leeds]], entitled ''Pedantic and Whimsical'', which was largely a "greatest hits" set of his material to date. He has also appeared in ''[[Father Ted]]'', and performed voice-over work in the [[Carphone Warehouse]] adverts. In February 2007 Byrne appeared on a [[comedian]]s' special edition of ''[[The Weakest Link]]''. Byrne has performed six sell-out shows at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] and three sell-out UK tours. He has also developed huge success on the international circuit where he has performed to full capacity audiences in [[Canada]], France, Australia, New Zealand and the United States.{{cite web |url=http://www.spoonfed.co.uk/artist/comedy-1524/ed-byrne-18071/ |website=Spoonfed.co.uk |title=Ed Byrne |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928040206/http://www.spoonfed.co.uk/artist/comedy-1524/ed-byrne-18071/ |archivedate=28 September 2013}} He has since garnered a raft of major broadcast credits, including five U.S. appearances on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' ([[NBC]]). In July 2007, Byrne made his début at the [[Newbury Comedy Festival]], having participated in the Cat Laughs Comedy Festival in [[Kilkenny]] shortly before. He recorded a live DVD ''Different Class'' at The [[King's Theatre, Glasgow]], on 23 March 2009, which was released on 23 November of that year. On 15 September 2010, Byrne, along with 54 other public figures, signed an open letter published in ''[[The Guardian]]'', stating their opposition to [[Pope Benedict XVI]]'s state visit to the UK.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/sep/15/harsh-judgments-on-pope-religion |title=Letters: Harsh judgments on the pope and religion |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=16 September 2010 |location=London |date=15 September 2010}} Byrne frequently appears on BBC stand-up comedy programme ''[[Mock The Week]]'' as the most common guest panellist, having appeared on 40 episodes as of 21 July 2016. ===Television work=== One of Byrne's first TV appearances was on the ITV shows ''[[The Big Big Talent Show]]'' and ''[[Blind Date (UK game show)|Blind Date]]''. He also appeared in ''[[Father Ted]]'' as a teenager mocking Father Ted and two other priests on a phone chat line, in the episode "[[A Christmassy Ted]]". Byrne has presented television shows ''Uncut! Best Unseen Ads'' and ''Just for Laughs'', and is a regular guest on ''[[The Panel (Irish TV series)|The Panel]]'', ''[[HeadJam]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'' and ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]''. He has appeared on ''[[Blankety Blank|Lily Savage's Blankety Blank]]'',{{cite episode |series=Lily Savage's Blankety Blank |network=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] |airdate=3 June 2001}} ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[The Bubble (UK TV series)|The Bubble]]'', ''[[The Unbelievable Truth (radio show)|The Unbelievable Truth]]'', ''[[Bring Me the Head of Light Entertainment]]'' and ''[[We Need Answers]]''. He has also appeared on ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'' six times.{{cite web |url=http://edbyrne.biz/2009/12/11/see-ed-on-the-graham-norton-show-monday-december-14th/ |title=See Ed on The Graham Norton Show, Monday December 14th |website=edbyrne.biz |date=11 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124151320/http://edbyrne.biz/2009/12/11/see-ed-on-the-graham-norton-show-monday-december-14th/ |archivedate=24 January 2010}} Byrne featured in a series of comedy shorts on the [[Microsoft Network|MSN]] Video Channel{{cite web |url=http://specials.uk.msn.com/edbyrne/ |title=Ed Byrne |website=MSN |year=2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221023556/http://specials.uk.msn.com/edbyrne |archivedate=21 February 2007}} in which he discusses some of his pet hates, including [[smoking|occasional smokers]] and his girlfriend's [[snoring]]. Byrne appeared in the second part of the BBC2 programme ''[[Three Men in a Boat (TV Series)|Three Men Go to Scotland]]'' on 30 December 2010 whilst hitching a ride in order to reach the [[Cuillin]] mountains on [[Skye]] for his [[Munro#Bagging the Munros|Munro bagging]] attempt - climbing every mountain in Scotland over {{Convert|3000|ft}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.avalonuk.com/pressRelease/179 |title=Three Men Go To Scotland |website=AvalonUK.com |accessdate=12 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110117134527/http://www.avalonuk.com/pressRelease/179 |archivedate=17 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} On 31 March 2012, Byrne appeared on ''All Star Family Fortunes''. On 5 July 2012, Byrne appeared as a guest on ''[[The One Show]]''. Byrne presented segments during ''[[Volcano Live]]'' from 9 to 12 July.{{cite web |url=http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2012/8620.html |title=Bristol scientists feature on BBC Two's Volcano Live |date=4 July 2012 |website=[[University of Bristol]] |accessdate=11 July 2012}} He appeared on a celebrity version of ''[[The Chase (UK game show)|The Chase]]'' on 30 November 2013, where he successfully brought £117,000 through, a record for the programme.{{cite web |url= http://www.ukgameshows.com/ukgs/The_Chase |title=The Chase |website=UK Game Shows |year=2015 |accessdate=25 March 2015}} ''[[Dara and Ed's Great Big Adventure]]'', a 2015 three-part [[fly-on-the-wall]] television series, followed Byrne and [[Dara Ó Briain]] (friend and fellow Irish comedian) in their journey by car down the [[Pan-American Highway]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05pc177 |title=Dara and Ed's Great Big Adventure |website=[[BBC Two]] |accessdate=7 February 2018}} ===Acting=== {{External links|section|date=January 2015}} Byrne had a small part in the 2000 comedy film ''[[Rat (film)|Rat]]''. In 2001 Byrne was the main character in an [[RTÉ]]-produced [[sitcom]] entitled ''[[The Cassidys (TV series)|The Cassidys]]''. It was cancelled after one series. In 2005 he starred in the film, ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Zemanovaload|cs|3=Zemanovaload|vertical-align=sup}}''. The film is about John Davies (played by Byrne) who suffers from multiple obsessive compulsive disorders. When his current model girlfriend leaves him, he decides to replace her with the most attractive woman on the planet, Czech model Veronika Zemanová. The film follows his attempts to curb his old obsessions in order to meet his latest obsession - Veronika. Byrne played the part of Luke Dyson in a comedy film set in London called ''Are You Ready For Love'' for which he won an Angel award at the Monaco Film Festival as best supporting actor.{{cite web |url=http://www.monacofilmfestival.net/awards.htm#2006 |title=Award Winners, Angel Film Awards 2006 |website=[[Monaco International Film Festival]] |accessdate=7 February 2018}} Byrne plays the part of Irish radio presenter Dylan Dale in the British feature film version of [[Tony Hawks]]' book ''[[Round Ireland with a Fridge (film)|Round Ireland with a Fridge]]'' which was released in September 2010 and on DVD on 8 November 2010. In 2010, Byrne played Rob in the BBC television pilot ''[[Reunited (TV pilot)|Reunited]]''. ===Writing=== Since 2011, Byrne has written a column for the hillwalking magazine ''[[TGO Magazine|TGO]]'' in which he tries a different outdoor activity each month in the company of an expert. He also had a column in the ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' newspaper until January 2012.{{cite web |url=https://metro.co.uk/2012/01/30/ed-byrne-i-sat-on-my-own-testicle-the-other-day-it-was-excruciating-302468/ |title=Ed Byrne: I sat on my own testicle the other day – it was excruciating |newspaper=Metro News |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=25 March 2015}} ===Other=== In March 2013, Byrne hosted the [[18th Empire Awards]] in London.{{cite web |url= http://www.empireonline.com/awards2013/live/ |title=Jameson empire awards 2013 live blog |date=24 March 2013 |website=Empire.com |accessdate=25 March 2013 }} In June 2013 Byrne appeared in an advert for Tesco Mobile. Byrne made an appearance on the BBC programme ''[[Saturday Kitchen]]''. A feature of the show is the guest chooses two foods for Heaven & Hell, and Byrne was given his food heaven choice of Sticky Ribs. Byrne has appeared twice on [[Richard Herring's Leicester Square Theatre Podcast]], once in 2013 and again in 2017.{{cite web |last=Bruce |first=Dessau |title=News: News Acts Announced For Richard Herring's Podcast Interviews |url=https://www.beyondthejoke.co.uk/content/4005/news-news-acts-announced-richard-herrings-podcast-interviews |website=Beyond the Joke |accessdate=11 October 2017}} ==Personal life== Byrne believes his older brother Stephen was the funniest member of the family as a child. His younger brother Paul is a comedy director and has long been a fixture at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]].{{cite web |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/fringe/2013/fullmooners/ |title=Fullmooners - Edinburgh Fringe 2013 |website=British Comedy Guide |accessdate=21 January 2014}} He also has an older sister, Trish. Byrne married theatre publicist Claire Walker in 2008. The couple live in [[Essex]] and have two sons, the elder called Cosmo and the younger named Magnus.{{cite tweet |first=Ed |last=Byrne |user=MrEdByrne |number=308163626576003072 |date=3 March 2013 |title=Despite what it says in The Observer... |access-date=25 March 2015}} Fellow comic [[Dara Ó Briain]] was best man at his wedding, returning the favour after Byrne was previously Ó Briain's best man in 2006.{{cite news |last=Leadbeater |first=Chris |title=Dara O’Briain and Ed Byrne head east on the Road to Mandalay |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/asia/articles/dara-o-briain-ed-byrne-road-to-mandalay-south-east-asia/ |accessdate=12 October 2017 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=7 May 2017}} Byrne is an [[atheist]] and a patron of [[Humanists UK]].{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H42HGzynzX4 |title=Ed Byrne joins the Census Campaign |website=YouTube |date= |accessdate=12 January 2014}} Byrne is an alumnus of the [[University of Strathclyde]]. ==Books== * ''Sit-Down Comedy'' (contributor to anthology, eds. [[Malcolm Hardee]] & John Fleming) Ebury Press/Random House, 2003. {{ISBN|0-09-188924-3}}; {{ISBN|978-0-09-188924-1}} ==Stand-up DVDs== {| class="wikitable" |- !Title !Released !Notes |- | ''Pedantic and Whimsical'' | 21 August 2006 | Live at [[Leeds City Varieties]] |- | ''Different Class'' | 23 November 2009 | Live at [[King's Theatre, Glasgow|Glasgow King's Theatre]] |- | ''Crowd Pleaser'' | 28 November 2011 | Live at [[Newcastle City Hall]] |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote|Ed Byrne}} * {{IMDb name|id=0126170|name=Ed Byrne}} * {{Official website|http://www.edbyrne.com/}} * [http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/e/91/ed_byrne Chortle page, including upcoming tour dates] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080929114540/http://www.suchsmallportions.com/allnew/uk_comedy/pages/live_just-the-tonic-bloomsbury.html Ed Byrne live at UCL Bloomsbury, May 2008, review from suchsmallportions.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070302190140/http://comedy.cqdweb.co.uk/ed_byrne.htm Profile, from Comedy Laid Bare] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080807222321/http://www.edcomfest.com/shows/Ed_Byrne_Different_Class Ed Byrne at the Edinburgh Comedy Festival 2008] {{Meteor Music Awards hosts}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Byrne, Ed}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Strathclyde]] [[Category:Irish atheists]] [[Category:Irish male comedians]] [[Category:Irish expatriates in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Irish stand-up comedians]] [[Category:People from Swords, Dublin]] [[Category:20th-century Irish male actors]] [[Category:21st-century Irish male actors]] [[Category:Irish male television actors]] [[Category:Irish male film actors]] [[Category:Male actors from Dublin (city)]]
